title: Work, Not Practice: The Studio Jones
description: “My view out the window in the Studio is not big enough to distract me, if I don’t want it to. It’s fine if I do want it to.” ---Phillip Johnson, 1999 The Glass House Stemming from the fatigue and over use of the word “practice” this seminar is intended to address what making a body of work truly means. The course will examine the artist’s studio as a place of labor, resistance, isolation, a ‘zone’ of genuine self-discovery, process and contemplation—indeed a psychological ‘space’ that may or may not always be a physical one. Because an artwork is more than just the proposition of an idea, we will attempt to collectively unpack the cultural currency related to being a working artist. Questions of audience and institution as ever present interlopers in the creative process will be addressed, as well as the potential commodification of ones identity. The class will involve peer-to-peer skill sharing, readings, screenings, guest speakers and a field trip. In short, Work Not Practice is a six session 1.5-credit experimental course focused on: Process, Studio Strategies, and Creative Practicality. **This class is limited to 12 to allow for intimacy and focused discourse.** This course meets on the following days: 1/31, 2/14, 3/7, 3/28, 4/11, and 4/25
